reviewText:
Fantastic Game.

Versus shmup action that is messy, hilarious, fast paced and most importantly fun.
It's a game were you shoot patterns of enemies which create fireballs that your opponent must either dodge or return. under correct circumstances the game quickly changes from a gallery shoot to a bullet hell in a heartbeat.

I do have to admit that this is not the best version of the game.

The dreamcast version had a series of options that fixed a few known issues, such as the score bug glitch. the slowdown and also had an option to run exclusive CD quality audio that was recorded for console releases. It is a shame that SNK continues to ignore these options that have been used in the past, espically if you concider that other dreamcast emulations have shown up on steam.

HOWEVER

It's available. It's on steam. It has online play. The basics are still there, and if this is all we are getting at the moment then I still recommend you wet your feet on this version. If this is what it takes to bring exposure to the game then so be it.
voteText: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I hate to give this a thumbs-down, as this is one of the most unique Neo Geo games— a competitive shoot-em-up with attacks & boss battles. However there are some glaring issues, stopping this port from doing justice to the arcade classic.

The music playback is wonky, and not just a little bit wonky. The emulation can't keep the beat at all, fouling the soundtrack from the stage BGM to the jingles. My i7-4930K is not starved for horsepower, so I don't know what the deal is.

The next issue isn't a problem per se, but the game runs at full speed without slowdowns, unlike the original Neo Geo game and certain ports (Saturn, Dreamcast). Maybe some prefer this, but I'm used to the game slowing to a crawl when the on-screen chaos ramps up, allowing me to thread the needle between myriad projectiles. It's not the same without that bullet-time behavior.

The third issue is a minor annoyance. The game forgets my resolution preference every time, resetting to 1024x768.

This port does have online multiplayer, which is cool I suppose, but I'll stick to other ways of satiating my nostalgia.

reviewText: Love it! My only previous experience is with the Dreamcast version and this is a huge boost in my opinion. The option for high resolutions, scan lines, and custom controls without messing around with external emulation is fantastic. I have experienced the issue, some have reported, that the selected resolution does not stay after restarting the game but all other settings have stuck (incuding custom controls). I don't think the resolution issue is a huge deal since we're dealing with a pixelated game (outside of the fancy menus). I have not experienced any of the other bugs" or issues that people are reporting
date:
such as audio problems or incorrect scores. Twinkle Star Sprites is still a fun spin on the usual shmup gameplay.

PROS:
+High resolution menus
+Resolution options
+Controller support
+Custom controls
+Scanlines
+Classic shoot em up gameplay with a 1v1 twist
+Online and local multiplayer
+Reasonable achievements (if you're into those)
+Leaderboards
+Cloud saves

CONS:
-Resolution choice does not stick after restart (may be patched)
-Not many people are going to be playing this game online

reviewText: Twinkle Star Sprites is a unique take on the shoot'em up genre. Players compete via split-screen to defeat enemies and outlast their opponent. While unable to attack each other directly, you can summon fireballs, minions or boss-monsters to overwhelm your opponent. You send more for performing combos, where defeating an enemy causes them to explode and defeat nearby enemies. Because of this mechanic proving more effective than shooting every enemy down individually or via bombs, there is a action-puzzle game feeling to the whole experience, trying to line up enemies for the largest possible combo before shooting them down.\n\nThe cute and colorful graphics and characters really give the game its charm. Each character also feels very unique in their attack arsenal and movement speeds, with decent balance among them, though some may take longer than others to get used to using or fighting against (with only the ultra-final boss possibly challenging the game balance as a secret character). For better or for worse, there is also this game's share of Engrish to explore, including having main character's name labeled as Load Ran" (presumedly originally intended to be Lord Ran? *shrug*
date: it's well established to be Load Ran now)\n\nHowever
recommended: there are some flaws with this game. There is currently a bug (which was also in the original) relating to scores
hoursPlayed: which is bad considering this game uses leaderboards. There are also some instances of the music stuttering or doubling up. Lag relating to overpopulating the screen with bullets/enemies has been reduced
voteText: which I would consider a good thing

column17: or those looking for a unique versus experience."

reviewText:
EDIT 2 (6/3/16): As of a few hours ago, the game got patched. The slowdown seems to be fixed and the video options don't reset anymore. The sound seems good too. I haven't been able to test the online multiplayer again yet, but even so I can now give this port a solid recommendation. I'll leave my pre-patch review here marked though, for posterity.

Now please patch Raiden Legacy to run at 54fps and we'll be golden, DotEmu.

ORIGINAL REVIEW (Pre-patch)
This is one of my favorite NeoGeo titles, and also one of my favorite shmups ever made thanks to its unique 1v1 take on the genre. I'm very familiar with the original title as well as its Dreamcast port, and I have to say, this one on the PC is trash.

Sound emulation is very poor, when booting up the game's character select screen the audio tends to loop over itself immediately. I ran into a bug the first time I tried to play the game where my stick just stopped working for no reason (luckily only in character selection and in single player, but that's still unacceptable). Online has very noticeable input lag, feels like you're sliding around everywhere, which makes it that much more difficult to dodge incoming fire. Speaking of dodging, there seems to be very little effort put into emulating slowdown when there's too many bullets on screen, making dodging heavy attacks far FAR more difficult. This was also an issue on the Dreamcast port, but they had the sense to include a NeoGeo mode in the options which restored this slowdown.

Another mark of shame upon you, DotEmu. I'd rather play this on my hacked NeoGeo X.

EDIT: I'd like to point out that the emulation of the Humble Bundle version of this game, released just a few months ago also by DotEmu, is far superior. What happened!?
